messages.text: Downsampling is usually used for two purposes: reducing query time over long time ranges and reducing the required storage size. VictoriaMetrics is optimized for both cases - it may quickly perform queries over long time ranges containing hundreds of millions of datapoints; it compresses data much better comparing to competitors. So it may work quite good withoit downsampling. An additional benefit is that you can drill down old data to low time ranges without precision loss

messages.text: Good point. Another question. We refactor our message structures quite often, e.g. rename data attributes. We currently use mySQL db and use the attribute names for the columns. This is quite cumbersome to automate and takes a lot of time if the amount of data in the db is big. How could we solve these problems with VictoriaMetrics?

text_entities.text: Good point. Another question. We refactor our message structures quite often, e.g. rename data attributes. We currently use mySQL db and use the attribute names for the columns. This is quite cumbersome to automate and takes a lot of time if the amount of data in the db is big. How could we solve these problems with VictoriaMetrics?

text: VictoriaMetrics has no db scheme - you can rename data attributes (they are named
or

in Prometheus and VictoriaMetrics world) or add / remove any attributes any time you want. The only issue is that every such modification in data attributes will result in new time series, since a time series is uniquely identified by name plus a set of

labels. It is recommended to keep such modifications low in order to reduce time series churn rate and reduce the number of unique time series in the db. Otherwise high cardinality problem may arise. Though VictoriaMetrics is better optimized for high cardinality data comparing to competitors, it is advisable to keep the number of unique time series under control. Read the following docs about high cardinality:
-

text: Hi! No, data doesn’t get copied. I guess,

meant that combination of timeseries name, labels and label values are used for building the lookup index. For the optimal performance lookup index should fit into the RAM. Having timeseries with high cardinality will increase index size, and potentially decrease performance. So it is better to avoid using for example client IP address as label or label value.

messages.text: Old data isn't copied. Just new time series is created and all the new data points are added to the new time series. VictoriaMetrics groups data points for each time series into blocks optimized for high on-disk compression ratio and high query performance. The compression ratio and query performance increases with the number of data points per time series. So it is recommended to store many data points in each time series instead of creating many time series with small number of data points in each of them.

So it is recommended to store many data points in each time series instead of creating many time series with small number of data points in each of them.

messages.text: I was wondering is there any limits on label characters, length and number of labels in VM? How does it affect performance if you increase the number of labels per metric?

text_entities.text: I was wondering is there any limits on label characters, length and number of labels in VM? How does it affect performance if you increase the number of labels per metric?

text:
There are no limits on label chars, but there are limit on label sizes:
- label name is limited by 256 chars
- label value is limited by 16K chars
- the total number of labels per time series is limited by 30
See the corresponding limits in
The ingestion performance decreases with the increased number of labels. See the last two charts showing insert performance for 2 and 10 labels per time series -
. Select performance shouldn't depend significantly on the number of per-timeseries labels.

messages.text:
Cool. 30 is a bit low, our old agent could add 25 or so just adding all the instance labels on a node running on a cloud provider but we also had restrictions for same reasons (ours were 50 labels per metric) but even that limit meant we had to rewrite plugins and not apply common labels to all metrics from an instance to stay under that limit which meant some users couldn’t slice and dice the dashboards easily or had to edit plugins to add specific instance metrics. 

Does Prometheus have similar limits to that and do all the exporters conform to that limit? Also is that a hard limit or something that could be improved over time?

messages.text: Hi, what do you recommend for the following: We get 32bit integer coded state and alarm information from devices. These are mainly list of booleans indicating warning, alarm, or operating (on/off) information. Would you store the 32bit integer values to get the history of the device protocol, or the single boolean state information  to track the change of events, or both which we would like (but currently don't with our mySQL approach)?  The individual bits can get massive >1500 per device, ~100 devices. The data is published once per second, or every 10 seconds and on change. It is important to track the time of the data change as accurate as possible to analyse the root in case of an event.

text_entities.text: Hi, what do you recommend for the following: We get 32bit integer coded state and alarm information from devices. The individual bits can get massive >1500 per device, ~100 devices. The data is published once per second, or every 10 seconds and on change. It is important to track the time of the data change as accurate as possible to analyse the root in case of an event.

messages.text: It would be better storing individual timeseries for each bit. The meaning of the bit may be stored either in metric name or label. Additional labels may be added for better filtering / grouping of state bits when querying

Hi, I am pretty new at promql, victoriametrics, influxdb, but I managed to setup a single-node VictoriaMetrics. My question is, how can I insert with a chosen timestamp? Because now it is generated automatically. I use line protocol:
curl -d 'measurement,sensor=temp value=420' -X POST 'http://localhost:8428/write' 
for insert, and I should be able to give it a timestamp, like in the line protocol documentation: |measurement|,tag_set| |field_set| |timestamp|

text_entities.text:
Hi, I am pretty new at promql, victoriametrics, influxdb, but I managed to setup a single-node VictoriaMetrics. My question is, how can I insert with a chosen timestamp? Because now it is generated automatically. I use line protocol:
curl -d 'measurement,sensor=temp value=420' -X POST 'http://localhost:8428/write' 
for insert, and I should be able to give it a timestamp, like in the line protocol documentation: |measurement|,tag_set| |field_set| |timestamp|

messages.text: Am is misunderstanding something?
Just add the timestamp in nanoseconds to the end of line according to Influx line protocol. The timestamp is optional there. When it is missing, it is set to the current timestamp

text_entities.text: Just add the timestamp in nanoseconds to the end of line according to Influx line protocol. The timestamp is optional there. When it is missing, it is set to the current timestamp

messages.text: Note that the timestamp must be set in nanoseconds, not milliseconds or seconds

messages.text:
- Timestamps may be inserted in arbitrary order, but it would be more optimal if they are inserted in increasing order.
- An additional value with the duplicate timestamp will be stored in the database.

- Timestamps may be inserted in arbitrary order, but it would be more optimal if they are inserted in increasing order.
- An additional value with the duplicate timestamp will be stored in the database.

messages.text: VictoriaMetrics supports backfilling, i.e. data with timestamps in the past may be inserted at any time

URL format
URLs for data ingestion: /insert/<accountID>/<suffix>, where:

<accountID> is an arbitrary number identifying namespace for data ingestion (aka tenant)
<suffix> may have the following values:
prometheus - for inserting data with Prometheus remote write API
influx/write or influx/api/v2/write - for inserting data with Influx line protocol

messages.text: but anyways thanks for response

Cloudwatch is prohibitevly expensive - 1M active time series with 60 second scrape interval would cost $0.02*1M=$20K per month. This results in 1M/60 = 17K samples / sec ingestion rate and 1M*60*24*30=43.2 billion samples per month. VictoriaMetrics can process such amount of data on an instance with a single CPU core, 1GB of RAM and 100GB persistent disk (EBS).  A year-worth data would require ~1TB of persistent storage. You can calculate costs - they should be much cheaper than Amazon Cloudwatch.

messages.text: hi, guys, I want know if i can use a label as userID in single vm process to support multi-tenent? will this slow vm down, or have any affections?

text_entities.text: hi, guys, I want know if i can use a label as userID in single vm process to support multi-tenent? will this slow vm down, or have any affections?

messages.text: Hi! There are no restrictions and it depends only on the cardinality of that label. So if you have 1k of userID you multiply all the timeseries by 1k.

text_entities.text: Hi! There are no restrictions and it depends only on the cardinality of that label. So if you have 1k of userID you multiply all the timeseries by 1k.

messages.text: It also depends on the hardware and your setup. For example, VM needs ~1KB of RAM for every unique timeseries it has. So it is easy to calculate required RAM by multiplying the total number of timeseries X number of userIDs X 1KB

text_entities.text: It also depends on the hardware and your setup. For example, VM needs ~1KB of RAM for every unique timeseries it has. So it is easy to calculate required RAM by multiplying the total number of timeseries X number of userIDs X 1KB

text:
Hi all!
We are going to re-design our landing page at
. The new landing page will contain
section with short decscription of successful cases from our users. It would be great if you could send short answers to the following questions to

:

- Your company name. What does the company do?
- Please explain your use case. It would be great to present a few numbers like ingestion rate, the total number of active time series, churn rate, the total number of Prometheus instances, select requests rate, etc.
- Which alternatives did you try?
- Why did you decide to use VictoriaMetrics?
- Which VictoriaMetrics setup do you use? Single-node or cluster version? How many CPU cores? RAM size? Disk size? Retention? The average CPU load and RAM usage for VM?
- What do you like the most in VictoriaMetrics?

Thanks for your help!

messages.text:
Hi, first of all I wanted to thank you for the cool software

and I’ve got a little question and would be grateful if you could shed some light on it

it's related to "vmstorage" role of the cluster version of VictoriaMetrics:

does it support some kind of data rebalancing like Cassandra?

for example, let's assume that I'm going to begin with one vmstorage pod with 1TB of volume. Then after some time the load increases so I decide to scale out the statefulset to 2 pods. At the time of scaling I have 90% of the volume space on the first pod already in use while the new one has no data. What would happen to the data?

text_entities.text:
Hi, first of all I wanted to thank you for the cool software

and I’ve got a little question and would be grateful if you could shed some light on it

it's related to "vmstorage" role of the cluster version of VictoriaMetrics:

does it support some kind of data rebalancing like Cassandra?

for example, let's assume that I'm going to begin with one vmstorage pod with 1TB of volume. Then after some time the load increases so I decide to scale out the statefulset to 2 pods. At the time of scaling I have 90% of the volume space on the first pod already in use while the new one has no data. What would happen to the data?

messages.text:
Hi! Thanks!

>> does it support some kind of data rebalancing like Cassandra?
Unfortunately vmstorage doesn’t support rebalancing. What you can do is to re-ingest data into new cluster:
* export all data from dev cluster
* spin-up new cluster
* replay exported data pushing it to the new cluster.
We don’t have components to make this process easier, but will consider to implement them in future.

>> What would happen to the data?
VMinsert and VMselect apps are configured separately, so you can exclude shard1 from ingestion path. Then eventually, when retention period comes, data between two shards will be balanced and shard1 may be returned to ingestion configuration.

text_entities.text:
Hi! Thanks!

>> does it support some kind of data rebalancing like Cassandra?
Unfortunately vmstorage doesn’t support rebalancing. What you can do is to re-ingest data into new cluster:
* export all data from dev cluster
* spin-up new cluster
* replay exported data pushing it to the new cluster.
We don’t have components to make this process easier, but will consider to implement them in future.

>> What would happen to the data?
VMinsert and VMselect apps are configured separately, so you can exclude shard1 from ingestion path. Then eventually, when retention period comes, data between two shards will be balanced and shard1 may be returned to ingestion configuration.

messages.text: Understood, thank you, Roman.

messages.text:
Hello everyone and thank you for the awesome software !
At our company, we are contemplating switching to Victoria Metrics. However, we would need a finer form of access control in order to prevent any compromised service from impersonating another and poisoning its label space. At the bare minimum, we need multiple users (http auth username/password pairs), and label restrictions for each of them.
Is such a feature currently supported ? (I can't find it)
If not, are there plans to implement it ? or known workarounds ?

text: Hi
! There is no auth feature in VictoriaMetricts yet, but we'll be glad helping with its implementation on a contract basis. Just drop us email at

with initial requirements for the auth system.
In the mean time you can try third-party Oauth proxy, which authorizes incoming queries on labels - see
and
for details.

text: Hi

, thank you for your answer. However, what we are looking for it not to allow certain users to see the metrics of certain services, but to only allow a given authenticated service to export stats with a given value for the "source" label, in order to prevent compromised services from poisoning the metrics of other services (regardless of the end user who is watching the grafana interface). Kind of oauth, but the other way around because we are not restricting what users can see, but what services can export towards Victoria Metrics :). It could be implemented either within Victoria Metrics, or as a proxy between the services and Victoria Metrics.

text: The

graph suggests that you constantly add 3K-5K of new time series per second during the last 30 minutes. This results in 4K*30*60=7.2M new time series for the last 30 minutes or 7.2*2*24=345.6M of new time series per day if the churn rate will remain the same during 24 hours. This is quite high churn rate. Could you provide a sample of labels per each time series? It looks like there are highly volatile labels there such as timestamp, uuid or client ip. It isn't recommended saving such labels, since they lead to high churn rate and high cardinality issues. See

.

You also mentioned that each time series has 45 labels (tags). By default VictoriaMetrics supports up to 30 labels per time series. The remaining labels are dropped. This limit can be adjusted with

command-line flag. What is the purpose of such a big number of labels per time series? Note that higher number of labels means higher memory usage and slower performance for both data ingestion and for querying, since more data must be stored and queried in caches and in inverted index.

text: It looks like the current VictoriaMetrics setup is able to register up to 5K new time series per second according to

graph. This means it will take 200M/5K/3600 = 11 hours to generate all the 200M time series. But currently it uses 10-20% of available CPU and disk IO bandwidth according to the screenshot above. This means in theory the system can register up to 5K/0.2=25K of new time series per second. The  process should take slightly more than 2 hours for 200M time series.

Try increasing the number of concurrent inserts into the current system. The optimal number of concurrent inserts for maximum ingestion rate is

available in VictoriaMetrics system.

You can extrapolate the performance for 200CPU core system from the current system.

messages.text: Thanos feels completely insane too me, with all the data it is  shoveling back and forth. Currently we have 2 weeks of data in Victoria which just uses 7 GB of disk and about 10 GB of RAM. While Thanos receiver alone needs 30 GB of disk for 6h of retention. And then it shovels all of that up to s3, Just to download it again for compaction and then upload the compacted things again... The Compactor needs 100 GB of disk. I could rant even longer

Currently we have 2 weeks of data in Victoria which just uses 7 GB of disk and about 10 GB of RAM. While Thanos receiver alone needs 30 GB of disk for 6h of retention. And then it shovels all of that up to s3, Just to download it again for compaction and then upload the compacted things again... The Compactor needs 100 GB of disk. I could rant even longer

messages.text: The thing is, victoria looks so much better in comparison that I can almost not believe it, I always have the feeling it tricks me somehow by not storing all the data and i just haven't noticed it yet or so :)

for details.

text:
Hello! Which exact component you define as client?
The following explanation would be based on assumption that you want to build a solution for storing and quering metrics.

A "heart" of such solution in our case is VictoriaMetrics TSDB. It allows to store and query timeseries without pre-defined scheme. Basically, it will store anything you put in if it satisfies following layout:
Number and combinations of

can be arbitrary and allows to express most of observations you might want to store. Pls let me know if you need additional info about this.

There are various ways to write metrics into VictoriaMetrics TSDB. It can "scrape" metrics ("pull" model) by querying configured "targets" (http addresses) or you can write metrics into it ("push" model). If you're familiar with Prometheus scraping model, then VictoriaMetrics is a "drop-in" replacement for it - can be configured with the same configs, scrape same targets, execute same queries. You also can configure telegraf client with  VictoriaMetrics URL and it will "write" metrics directly into it.

The advanced way to "deliver" metrics to VictoriaMetrics TSDB is

. Vmagent is a separate lightweight service that shares the same features as VM: can scrape, can accept write requests. Vmagent is more lightweight because it has no TSDB in it, hence it is easy to setup and maintain. For example, you can setup multiple vmagents per k8s cluster, datacenter or subset of services and configure them to write into a single VM TSDB.
Vmagent could be aslo used as "fanout" service, that accepts metrics and writes them into multiple destinations. User can configure multiple URLs that support RemoteWrite protocol and vmagent will deliver metrics to each of them. This is mostly used for building HA setups.
Vmagent is tolerant to network issues. If connection to VM TSDB breaks it starts to buffer accepted metrics on disk. When connection restores - it re-reads buffered data and sends it to VM. The buffer size in bytes is controlled by

flag, where URL stands for every configured destination. 
The more details about usage patter for vmagent could be found here

messages.text:
I'm afraid I don't understand the question. 
There are multiple options how you can use VM:
- configure VM as remote storage for Prometheus
- configure VM to scrape your services just like Prometheus does
- push metrics into VM direclty from your services.
Is your intention just to test how VM works or you're trying to achieve something different?

messages.text:
after changes of serviceScrapeSelector for empty value, you have to wait some time, usually it takes 1-2 mins for kubernetes secret changes sync happens. 

How it works: operator lists vmServiceScrapes, writes logs message for selected vmServiceScrapes (you can check it at operator's log), builds configuration for vmagent and writes it to the secret, mounted to vmagent's pod. Then kuberentes updates secret content and vmagent reloads configuration.

text: You mean cpu/memory usage ?  Its related to kubernetes cluster monitoring. There is cadvisor metrics, that kubelet exports. It can be scraped with additionalScrapeConfig. I'm using this configuration:

text.text:
apiVersion: v1
kind: Secret
metadata:
  name: additional-scrape-configs
  namespace: monitoring-system
stringData:
  additional.yaml: |
    - job_name: 'kubernetes-cadvisor'
      scheme: https
      tls_config:
        ca_file: /var/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/ca.crt
        insecure_skip_verify: true
      bearer_token_file: /var/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/token
      kubernetes_sd_configs:
        - role: node
      relabel_configs:
        - action: labelmap
          regex: __meta_kubernetes_node_label_(.+)
        - target_label: __address__
          replacement: kubernetes.default.svc:443
        - source_labels: [__meta_kubernetes_node_name]
          regex: (.+)
          target_label: __metrics_path__
          replacement: /api/v1/nodes/$1/proxy/metrics/cadvisor
----
apiVersion: operator.victoriametrics.com/v1beta1
kind: VMAgent
metadata:
  name: example-vmagent
  namespace: monitoring-system
spec:
 ....
  replicas: 1
  additionalScrapeConfigs:
    name: additional-scrape-configs
    key: additional.yaml
....

text: Yep, for now you can use additional config for vmagent to scrape metrics from cadvisor.

text.text:
apiVersion: v1
kind: Secret
metadata:
  name: additional-scrape-configs
  namespace: monitoring-system
stringData:
  additional.yaml: |
    - job_name: 'kubernetes-cadvisor'
      scheme: https
      tls_config:
        ca_file: /var/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/ca.crt
        insecure_skip_verify: true
      bearer_token_file: /var/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/token
      kubernetes_sd_configs:
        - role: node
      relabel_configs:
        - action: labelmap
          regex: __meta_kubernetes_node_label_(.+)
        - target_label: __address__
          replacement: kubernetes.default.svc:443
        - source_labels: [__meta_kubernetes_node_name]
          regex: (.+)
          target_label: __metrics_path__
          replacement: /api/v1/nodes/$1/proxy/metrics/cadvisor
        - source_labels: [__meta_kubernetes_node_name]
          target_label: kubernetes_io_hostname
        - source_labels: ["pod"]
          target_label: "pod_name"

messages.text:
I think encryption is a task for the underlying filesystem, so it is unlikely the PR will be merged. Moreover, encryption is hard to implement properly. For example, how do you plan to pass encryption keys to VictoriaMetrics? If they are passed via command-line or via environment variables, then an attacker can easily read them if he has access to the machine where VictoriaMetrics runs. How do you plan to store encryption keys in memory? If an attacker has access to the machine with VM, then it can read these keys from the memory of VM process. How do you plan to rotate encryption keys? Which encryption algrotythm and which encryption mode do you plan to use for the data? There are many such questions, which are hard to implement properly. So it is better relying on specialized filesystems with proper encryption support.

IMHO, it is better to do not provide encryption in VictoriaMetrics at all than providing snake oil encryption.

text_entities.text:

How do you plan to store encryption keys in memory? If an attacker has access to the machine with VM, then it can read these keys from the memory of VM process. How do you plan to rotate encryption keys? Which encryption algrotythm and which encryption mode do you plan to use for the data? There are many such questions, which are hard to implement properly. So it is better relying on specialized filesystems with proper encryption support.

IMHO, it is better to do not provide encryption in VictoriaMetrics at all than providing snake oil encryption.

messages.text: It is recommended splitting long JSON lines with lengths exceeding a few megabytes into shorter lines in order to reduce memory usage during data import, since VictoriaMetrics loads line contents in memory and then parses it. For example, if a time series with 10M samples must be imported into VM, then split this time series into 100 chunks with 100K samples per each chunk and then put each chunk in a separate JSON line during import. Each chunk should contain the same set of labels for the imported time series.

. It is likely the gaps are related to duplicate samples. VictoriaMetrics stores all the ingested data including samples with duplicate timestamps. Probably you imported the same data multiple times, which could result in duplicate samples in the database. that are shorter than 2x detected scrape interval. Duplicate samples can break proper detection of scrape interval, which  may result in gaps on the graph. See docs about export api -

text: Hi

I exported /api/v1/export-ed my 'nongo*' mongodb diagnostics timeseries that showed gaps when queried out again. In the export data there are no duplicates. The jsonline data exported is exactly the same as jsonline data imported in.
(Well, there is one difference - the jsonline file I imported had an empty string for one label value. ("cl_id": "") and the export file does not include it. But that is also true for the series that includes every-second, often-duplicate values that doesn't have the gap issue. So it doesn't seem to be a factor.)

messages.text:
On the good side - the data that was imported exists, according the /api/v1/export endpoint. Clearly there is no ingestion process bug that is discarding data points before they are saved.
The bad side is that /api/v1/query_range is serving it back with gaps.
(And that the idea of duplicated points that was your first guess is not correct).
(Well, not according to the evidence of the export produced in jsonline format. Is there any point to taking it again in native or csv format?)

Hi folks, Is there has any good scheme for hot backup? My IoT situation is not very complex; therefore, the single-node version is quite satisfied. However, how to handle data loss is a headache problem for me, I want to achieve such idea, Two servers that are simultaneously running the VM single-node, the VM A is the main and the VM B is the backup one, VM B always maintains the same data with VM A.

I try to use vmagent to achieve it; namely, the data would send to vmagent in server A, then this vmagent send the data to VM A and B both.

messages.text: Hello, i like scheme with vmagent.  Its also possible to write from 2 vmagents in both vmsingles and enable deduplication at vmsingle side. It brings high-availability for vmagent. But also increase resource usage at vmsingles and network usage.Some nginx or other proxy server can be placed in front of vmsingle for client queries.

text: could you please help

> Any recommendations on how to visualize and slience alerts?

By visualization you mean how to display list of alerts (like
) or plot time series for alerts state (like

)?
If first - vmalert displays list of configured and active alerts via web api (without styles unfortunately) - see
If second - vmalert writes such time series if

flag is configured. Basically, vmalert will write ALERTS and ALERTS_FOR_STATE metrics to the configured storage.
Silencing of alerts wasn't possible in Prometheus either. In both cases you'll need to interact with AlertManager

text:
> Any best practices?

vmalert is stateless, so you can run more than 1 vmalert for HA. Even if multiple vmalerts will generate the same alert, AlertManager can be configured to de-duplicate them.
vmalert exposes own metrics on the

page. Metrics contain info per-alert, so you may find it useful
vmalert supports MetricsQL, so you can benefit from it as well.
You can find example of vmagent+vm+vmalert+alertmanager setup here

text: This is true. Grafana alerts aren’t as reliable as Prometheus/vmalert solution. Also, AlertManager gives much more flexibility for managing alerts. Basically, any company I know about which are using Prometheus or VictoriaMetrics are also using AlertManager. So I think, it is totally ok to use AlertManager. Many also use

as addition.
Btw, Grafana alerting system still can be used for some non-important alerts, building PoC, validating theories. You also can display alerts status from vmalert/prometheus in Grafana by just querying their metrics.

text: VictoriaMetrics follows Prometheus data model when performing MetricsQL queries. Arithmetic operations like

are performed in the following way according to this data model:
1) To select all the time series for
and
parts of the query. For example
can select multiple time series with the given name
and the given labels
. These time series can differ by other labels:
and

.
2) To strip metric names from time series returned by
and
parts. I.e.
is transformed into nameless time series

.
3) To find time series for
and

parts with identical set of labels and to apply the given operation to them. If no identical time series are found, then an empty result is returned. This is likely your case.

The behavior at step 3 can be changed with special modifiers such as
and
. See more details about these modifiers at

.

See more information about arithmetic operations in PromQL and MetricsQL at

messages.text: Hi everyone, i have 2 instance of prometheus with cluster Victoriametrics. Everytime i refresh in grafana graphs(data source from vmselect) about count(kube_po_info) i receive diffrent values. I have solved it with max_over_time and restrict to data from only one instance. I know it isn't resolve a problem. And here is my question how can i compare 2 metrics and get max value over 10 min?

text_entities.text: Hi everyone, i have 2 instance of prometheus with cluster Victoriametrics. Everytime i refresh in grafana graphs(data source from vmselect) about count(kube_po_info) i receive diffrent values. I have solved it with max_over_time and restrict to data from only one instance. I know it isn't resolve a problem. And here is my question how can i compare 2 metrics and get max value over 10 min?

text: Try

- it should return the maximum value for the metric over the last 10 minutes.

The
can return different graphs with each call if the number of time series with

name changes over time, i.e. some time series stop receiving new samples, while samples for new time series start flowing in. A time series is uniquely identified by its name plus a set of its labels. If at least a single label value changes, then new time series is created. I.e.
and
are distinct time series. If you need more stable values from the query, then try the following query instead:

. It returns the number of active time series over the last 10 minutes. The lookbehind window in square brackets can be increased for obtaining the number of active time series over bigger time ranges.

As for two Prometheus instances that write data to VictoriaMetrics, there are two cases exist:
- Prometheus services scrape distinct set of targets. In this case it is recommended adding unique
or
label per Prometheus instance in
section as described at

. This will guarantee that metrics received from distinct Prometheus instances do not clash.

text_entities.text:
- it should return the maximum value for the metric over the last 10 minutes.

The
can return different graphs with each call if the number of time series with

name changes over time, i.e. some time series stop receiving new samples, while samples for new time series start flowing in. A time series is uniquely identified by its name plus a set of its labels. If at least a single label value changes, then new time series is created. I.e.
are distinct time series. If you need more stable values from the query, then try the following query instead:

. It returns the number of active time series over the last 10 minutes. The lookbehind window in square brackets can be increased for obtaining the number of active time series over bigger time ranges.

As for two Prometheus instances that write data to VictoriaMetrics, there are two cases exist:
- Prometheus services scrape distinct set of targets. In this case it is recommended adding unique

. This will guarantee that metrics received from distinct Prometheus instances do not clash.

- Both Prometheus scrape the same set of targets. This mode is known as HA setup. In this case deduplication must be enabled at vmselect and vmstorage nodes in order to remove duplicate samples received from Prometheus HA pair  See

text: It looks like the issue is related to automatic detection of the interval between datapoints. The
handler expects to work with time series with a constant interval between datapoints. Such an interval is called

in Prometheus ecosystem. The time series in your case contains datapoints with highly irregular interval between them if "undef" state isn't reported to VictoriaMetrics. So it improperly detects the scrape interval, which is then used for filling gaps in a time series during query execution if these gaps don't exceed 2x scrape interval. There are the following workarounds:
- To report "undef" state as 0 value to VictoriaMetrics at regular intervals. This shouldn't increase storage requirements too much, since VictoriaMaterics provides good compression for such data
- To specify

command-line flag to small value in order to limit the maximum detected interval between datapoints with irregular interval.
- To query raw datapoints via
. See

text:
Some facts about VictoriaMetrics and ClickHouse:
- VictoriaMetrics storage architecture is inspired by ClickHouse - see
and

- VictoriaMetrics is a specialized solution for monitoring. ClickHouse is a general-purpose analytical database, which can be used for monitoring. This means that VictoriaMetrics works out of the box for practical monitoring tasks, while ClickHouse needs to be configured for practical monitoring tasks. For example, you need to design a database schema optimally suited for the particular monitoring task in ClickHouse (this is non-trivial task in general case). Incorrectly chosen database schema in ClickHouse may result in sub-optimal performance and high resource usage. VictoriaMetrics is free from this issue, since it already contains the optimal database schema for practical monitoring tasks.
- VictoriaMetrics usually provides better compression rate than ClickHouse with the best database schema for monitoring data. This means that the data in VictoriaMetrics requires lower disk space than ClickHouse.
- VictoriaMetrics provides similar query performance compared to optimally tuned ClickHouse for typical monitoring queries.
- VictoriaMetrics provides MetricsQL query language tuned for monitoring queries, while ClickHouse provides SQL-like query language tuned for analytical queries.

text:
Monitoring queries are focused on processing only time series data, and it only works with text and float64 data types. It is not suitable for calculating uniques, aligning data to specific intervals, storing data with high cardinality (like UUIDs) etc. But it works extremly well for analyzing state or status of serivces/applications.
You may find more about analytics-vs-promql here
I also tried using ClickHouse for monitoring purposes and here's what I think about query language
(sorry for my English :-))

text:
Hello everyone!
We've released initial version of our All in One Helm Chart

text.text: This chart will do the following:

text:
- Rollout victoria metrics operator, grafana, prometheus-node-exporter and kube-state-metrics helm charts
- Create vmsingle, vmagent, vmalert,vmalertmanager CRDs
- Configure Grafana for VictoriaMetrics datasource
- Configure ServiceScrapes for Node Exporter, kube-state-metrics and various kubernetes metrics
- Install Grafana dashboards for kubernetes monitoring based on kube-prometheus

text:
> is there any dev team to VM apart the community contributors and who is doing the support ?
there is no another team, contributions and support are made by public contributors.

> As well is there any usage of telegraf / influx code ?
You can see the full list of dependencies here

The VM as TSDB does not use external dependencies. 
But some utility applications do. For example,
utility uses Prometheus (prometheus/tsdb, prometheus/storage) and Influx (influxdata/influxdb) libraries in order to provide migration functionality from these systems.

is missing (FreeBSD 13 has a new system for trusted certificates in base system, so that port is "more optional" than before) both Victoria and BlackBoxExporter fail to connect to any https port.

text_entities.text: Hi! I noticed that when the package

is missing (FreeBSD 13 has a new system for trusted certificates in base system, so that port is "more optional" than before) both Victoria and BlackBoxExporter fail to connect to any https port.
I know nothing about Go, in what directin should I look about "trusted root CA" resolution during TLS connections?

text: It looks like every Go application that uses TLS needs root CA certificates installed in default place. These CA certificates are used for verifying certificate signatures provided by peers during establishing TLS connections. That's why VictoriaMetrics needs
package. I think this package must be added as a dependency for VictoriaMetrics packages.

text_entities.text: thanks, then in what sutiation do we recommend to use vmagent？

text: Use cases for vmagent are described here

In two words, the main difference between VM and vmagent is that VM is a full-featured database, while vmagent is a lightweight agent for scraping and forwarding metrics. vmagent does not store metrics and can't serve read queries. Typically, people use vmagent-per-environment (different k8s clusters, engineering teams etc.) to scrape metrics and forward to a VM. 

If you're looking just for Prometheus replacing - use single-node VM. That's the most similar component: it scrapes metrics, stores them and can be used as datasource in Grafana. 

Vmagent is more for advanced usage and for cluster version of VM.

text_entities.text: Use cases for vmagent are described here

In two words, the main difference between VM and vmagent is that VM is a full-featured database, while vmagent is a lightweight agent for scraping and forwarding metrics. vmagent does not store metrics and can't serve read queries. Typically, people use vmagent-per-environment (different k8s clusters, engineering teams etc.) to scrape metrics and forward to a VM. 

If you're looking just for Prometheus replacing - use single-node VM. That's the most similar component: it scrapes metrics, stores them and can be used as datasource in Grafana. 

Vmagent is more for advanced usage and for cluster version of VM.

HI Everyone,
I’m trying the VM clustered version. I have a doubt on VMbackup on clustered version. Planning to run 3 VMstorage instance with replication enabled and set to 1. Want to store the backup in S3. Do I need to maintain three individual s3 buckets for 3 VMstorage instance or since vmbackup follow LSMTree structure maintaining one S3 bucket can have all the chunks of data from all three VMStorage. Looking forward for some clarification. Thank You

text_entities.text:
HI Everyone,
I’m trying the VM clustered version. I have a doubt on VMbackup on clustered version. Planning to run 3 VMstorage instance with replication enabled and set to 1. Want to store the backup in S3. Do I need to maintain three individual s3 buckets for 3 VMstorage instance or since vmbackup follow LSMTree structure maintaining one S3 bucket can have all the chunks of data from all three VMStorage. Looking forward for some clarification. Thank You

text: It is recommended storing backups from different vmstorage nodes to a single bucket, but with different path prefix (aka different folders). E.g.
for the first vmstorage,
for the second vmstorage, etc. Backups from different vmstorage nodes  cannot be stored to a single s3 folder, since they contain different data, which will be overwritten during each backup.

text_entities.text: It is recommended storing backups from different vmstorage nodes to a single bucket, but with different path prefix (aka different folders). E.g.
for the second vmstorage, etc. Backups from different vmstorage nodes  cannot be stored to a single s3 folder, since they contain different data, which will be overwritten during each backup.

text: Hi

! At any circumstances data that is being scraped once per day will need less disk space than data that is scraped every 10s, for example. So choose what is easier/better for you. The only things I'd are the following:
- if data changes rarely, then compression ratio will be very good. It is hard to say what would be the exact cost of this, but I think you account for something like 0.5 byte per data point. With this number you can approximately calculate the disk usage for these metrics. For example, if your target exposes 1000 metrics and srcape_interval is 10s, then you'll need 1000*0.5b*(86400/10)=4.3MB per day. Probably, that's the cost you can pay for not doing extra work)
- rarely scraped data can negatively impact querying experience, since such rare observations could be marked as "stale". It is recommended to have scrape interval < 5m or so. I'm not saying 1d scrape interval wouldn't work, but it may require some extra tweaks like wrapping your query for such metrics in "last_over_time" function or similar ones

yeah, sounds reasonable. Let me know if it will work for you. Last time I checked prometheus library for metrics it was extremly hard to remove previously existing metric from the registry and stop exporting it. And since node_exporter uses that library the issue may remain there as well.
That's also one of the reason we have our own lib for metrics -
It is very lightweight go-lib without extra dependencies. And it supports easy metrics deletion which we use in
to stop exposing metrics for rules which were removed from the configuration during the hot reload.

messages.text:
in CSV format you have columns for each unique label name. Hence, if you export all time series with all labels - the number of columns will be enormous. That's why API requires user to list all metric names and labels. The CSV format is good if you exactly know what you're exporting, like export all hostnames or instance names.
For the rest of cases use json format.

messages.text:
Vminsert needs to know about all the vmstorage nodes, since it shards incoming data among available vmstotage nodes. If vmstorage nodes will be placed behind a service, then the data distribution among vmstorage nodes will be non-optimal, which will result in increased resource usage (RAM, disk space, cpu) at vmstorage nodes.
Vmselect queries all the vmstorage nodes for each incoming request, since it cannot know in advance which vmstorage nodes contain the needed data. If vmstorage nodes will be placed behind a service, then each request from vmselect will go only to a single vmstorage node, so the result will be incomplete.

, so the in-memory buffer becomes full and it starts flushing the data to the
file on disk. I'd recommend monitoring
graph from the official dashboard for vmagent - see
. If the graph contains a line with zero values, then all the data fits in-memory buffer and isn't flushed to disk.

text: I see. So you're indeed seeing not "real" data points. That is one of the nuances when using
API (which Grafana uses for Prometheus/VictoriaMetrics datasources).
does not return raw values. It returns N data points for that series, where N = time_range/step. So if you have a 1 real datapoint every minute, the
will return
data points and

API will return only one datapoint.
The origin of such behaviour comes from pull model - Prometheus never provided a guarantee that metric will be scraped every 10s or so. Instead, Prometheus schedules the scrape job to execute when it is possible and there are resources to do so, but not frequently than
. Because of that, scrapes with
may happen on 11th sec, then on 15th sec, and then on 11th sec again. But if you will plot such data it will look "not fancy". That's why originial implementation of
returned always perfectly aligned datapoints, where ephemeral data points were just repeating previous "real" datapoint in that data range. And VictoriaMetrics is compatible with this behavior.

API will return only one datapoint.
The origin of such behaviour comes from pull model - Prometheus never provided a guarantee that metric will be scraped every 10s or so. Instead, Prometheus schedules the scrape job to execute when it is possible and there are resources to do so, but not frequently than
may happen on 11th sec, then on 15th sec, and then on 11th sec again. But if you will plot such data it will look "not fancy". That's why originial implementation of
returned always perfectly aligned datapoints, where ephemeral data points were just repeating previous "real" datapoint in that data range. And VictoriaMetrics is compatible with this behavior.

messages.text: However, calculations are always made with raw values, not ephemeral ones.

Hi! There is a difference between reading raw metrics and processed metrics.
Raw metrics can be obtained via export API -
Processed metrics (they're not equal to raw metrics for various reasons), rollups and metrics with functions applied can be obtained via Prometheus API -
I'm not aware of client for reading the metrics in Go.

text: The reason for a separate

is to cover a use case where the results of alerting and recording rules are written into a distinct database. This way you can set up recording rules, which will be evaluated against a short-term storage with high-frequency and high-cardinality samples, while the results will be written to a long-term storage with the decreased cardinality and bigger interval between samples.

text: Hi!

label is a preferred way, from what I know. It is totally ok to have totally different time series in different jobs.
From a technical perspective, both
and metric name - are just labels. So it doesnt matter how exactly you'll do this. Just choose what will be more convenient to use.

messages.text:
Hi, We use Victoria Metrics + Grafana for all monitoring tasks. But we have an issue with metrics that could change their values in past. For example data quality metrics should be recalculated with data (daily partitioned tables).

Possible workarounds: 1) Put date of partition to Label/tag, put current timestamp to timestamp of metric. It requires external aggregation (first value for a label) so forces to use Bar Gauge panel in grafana. It’s not a time-series data/plot then. 2) Put the same data structure to promscale. Use sql to transform the data (window function with first + cast label to timestamp). Needs extra db only for sql access. 3) Put something between vm and grafana panel that can transform json. Rest service or grafana plugin.

Does anybody know simple solution?

text:
Hi! That's a good question)
Unfrotunately, I'm not aware of a good answer on it.
The label tag idea seems interesting. You can add __meta_revision label to all your metrics (or only choosen ones) to identify the version. Then, bump __meta_revision value by 1 every time you backfill some metrics. Reading such data will require additional proxy to read and deduplicate data. For example:

In example above, proxy got two metrics in response from VM. It detected two revisions and merged both metrics into one, substituting values from ver=1 with values from ver=2 for identical timestamps.

Ofc, this looks like a workaround. I wish VM could provide more flexibility on cases like this. This worth a discussion. If you have ideas how it can be implemented - let us know or open feature request on github.

messages.text: Vm was preselected. Promscale doesn’t support metrics update/delete by time range too (it’s possible only via sql api). Looks like mutable metrics is out of scope for all tsdbs. text:
VictoriaMetrics processes matching time series one-by-one per each available cpu core. It loads, unpacks and processes raw samples in memory per each matching time series on the given time range. This means that the memory usage is proportional to the number of raw samples in a single matching time series on the selected time range multiplied by the number of available cpu cores. It doesn't depend on the number of matching time series, since they are processed serially. For example, if a query selects 10000 time series with 1000000 raw samples per each time series on the selected time range, and victoriametrics runs on a computer with 4 CPU cores, then it will need 1000000*4*16=64 MB of memory during execution.

VictoriaMetric keeps intermediate query results in memory until the query returns. The amounts of temporary query results depend on the number of output time series and on the number of calculated datapoints per each output time series. The number of datapoints equals to
, where start, end and step are query args passed to /api/v1/query_range - see
Subqueries may need big amoumts of temporary results stored in memory if the step value passed in
is too small compared to the selected time range.

We just prepared a Prod Environment with Single VM Binary Setup! Now We are planning to migrate data from Prometheus instance and remote-write all new metrics into VM.

Then We will monitor the VM via Grafana. If we fond the ingestion rates higher than a million of data points per second, Is there any option to migrate the Single VM data into cluster version?

mentioned that, there is no option to migrate data between Single VM and Cluster VM. In this case, How to expand the performance in Single VM? What is the recommended approach for switch to Cluster VM?

text: A single-node version of VictoriaMetrics can scale vertically, e.g. its' performance increases proportionally to the available CPU, RAM and disk IO resources. See

.

Switching from single-node to cluster version of VictoriaMetrics is needed if a single-node setup cannot be scaled vertically. Unfortunately there is no fast path for historical data migration from single-node to cluster version. The data can be migrated via vmctl (see

), but the migration process can take long time for big volumes of data.

Another approach for the migration from single-node to cluster version of VictoriaMetrics is to set up cluster version and write data in parallel to single-node and cluster versions for some time. This can be done via vmagent - see
. Single-node version of VictoriaMetrics can be shut down after some time when the cluster version will have enough data for performing all the needed queries.

), but the migration process can take long time for big volumes of data.

Another approach for the migration from single-node to cluster version of VictoriaMetrics is to set up cluster version and write data in parallel to single-node and cluster versions for some time. This can be done via vmagent - see
. Single-node version of VictoriaMetrics can be shut down after some time when the cluster version will have enough data for performing all the needed queries.

text: This is caused by the following change in 1.73 release:

text.text: FEATURE: vmagent and single-node VictoriaMetrics: disallow unknown fields at -promscrape.config file. Previously unknown fields were allowed. This could lead to long-living silent config errors. The previous behaviour can be returned by passing -promscrape.config.strictParse=false command-line flag.

messages.text:
Hi! There is no much sense in having only one vmstorage node. It is better to use a single-node version and scale it vertically.
Prefer single node version for simple installations and when there is an option for vertical scaling. Single node version is totally capable of handling ingestion of 3kk+ samples/s and 30kk of active series.

Prefer cluster version if you want to exceed limitations of one machine (exceed disk/network/memory/CPU resources) by splitting data into shards. The cluster version is capable of insane workloads up to billions of time series, just because you can scale and horizontally, and vertically.

Please note, for moderate workloads single version will be more efficient just because it has no network penalty (for communication between components). But at some point data sharding becomes more efficient as workload grows.

If you decide to go with cluster with plan to scale in future, it is better to have multiple shards from very beginning and then scale them vertically when time comes. Going this way you'll avoid common problems in distributed systems such as re-sharding, data imbalance, etc.

Prefer cluster version if you want to exceed limitations of one machine (exceed disk/network/memory/CPU resources) by splitting data into shards. The cluster version is capable of insane workloads up to billions of time series, just because you can scale and horizontally, and vertically.

Please note, for moderate workloads single version will be more efficient just because it has no network penalty (for communication between components). But at some point data sharding becomes more efficient as workload grows.

If you decide to go with cluster with plan to scale in future, it is better to have multiple shards from very beginning and then scale them vertically when time comes. Going this way you'll avoid common problems in distributed systems such as re-sharding, data imbalance, etc.

messages.text: If you build a graph for this query, then VictoriaMetrics calculates the query separately per each returned point on the graph. The number of poimts on the graph is usually quite big (e.g. 1000), so this mya slow down the query. If you need only a single result per day, then you need instant query instead of range query

text_entities.text:
Hello,
Could you so kindly explain to me data replication, please? I'm wondering if I lost one storage then restore or add new storage, will old data, saved on another storage, replicate automatically to newly added storage? I mean data synchronize among all storage.

text:
Hi! VictoriaMetrics implements replication on application level. It means, only "writers" (vminserts) and "readers" (vmselect) are aware of it. "vmstorage" nodes just store everything they receive, and return everything they asked for. 
On the one hand, such approach is very easy to understand and predict. It also significantly improves performance and maintainability of the cluster.
On the other hand, vmstorage nodes are not aware of the replication. So no automatic synchronization is possible.
Replication of old data to the new node should be performed manually via migration of all the data (just copying files over the network) or partially via migration utilities such as vmctl -

text:
Hi,
You can check this guide, though not completely describing your case can give some insights in HA monitroing setup:

Shortly, if one replica fails, same data is populated to the remaining cluster.
When 2 replicas working, they still share same data, depending on your replication factor and deduplication setup it can be customized further.

messages.text: Hey all. I'm trying to see if we can replace Datadog with VictoriaMetrics. I have no problem ingesting our high-cardinality metrics, but I'm not able to query them in a timely manner, or even at all. In my POC deployment, I have 12 storage pods with 12GiB of RAM and 4 CPU allocated, and 4 select pods with 8GiB RAM and 4 CPU. Still, my queries from the select pods to the storage time out. I have looked through the documentation to identify what resources I need to increase in order to increase performance, but it is not obvious to me. Ideally, I would like these queries to return results in only a few seconds. Pardon any ignorance on my part, I am reading documentation, but I only have one week of experience with VictoriaMetrics.

text_entities.text: Hey all. I'm trying to see if we can replace Datadog with VictoriaMetrics. I have no problem ingesting our high-cardinality metrics, but I'm not able to query them in a timely manner, or even at all. In my POC deployment, I have 12 storage pods with 12GiB of RAM and 4 CPU allocated, and 4 select pods with 8GiB RAM and 4 CPU. Still, my queries from the select pods to the storage time out. I have looked through the documentation to identify what resources I need to increase in order to increase performance, but it is not obvious to me. Ideally, I would like these queries to return results in only a few seconds. Pardon any ignorance on my part, I am reading documentation, but I only have one week of experience with VictoriaMetrics.

text:
VictoriaMetrics can process up to 50 million of raw samples per second per CPU core at vmselect during querying. The performance scales with the number of CPU cores at vmselect node. If your queries take too long time, then there may be the following issues:
* The query selects too many unique time series (aka high cardinality issue). The solution is to decrease time series cardinality.
* The query needs to process billions of raw samples.

See
for details on how to determine and eliminate the source of slow query

messages.text: OOMs are a sign of underprovisioning. Try to setup monitoring in order to understand resource usage of VM.

text_entities.text: OOMs are a sign of underprovisioning. Try to setup monitoring in order to understand resource usage of VM.

messages.text: 500 is the status code returned by server/process. If process goes OOM and is terminated by OS - it can't respond at all. It is the same like there is no running process there. So it is likely 500 is returned by something else, or is not related to OOM.

text_entities.text: 500 is the status code returned by server/process. If process goes OOM and is terminated by OS - it can't respond at all. It is the same like there is no running process there. So it is likely 500 is returned by something else, or is not related to OOM.

text:
my suggestions are the following:
- understand why VM goes OOM. Try to setup monitoring and check alert rules to get idea what is going on -
or for cluster version

- OOMs should not result to noticeable data gaps - the max you can lose is a one second of data which was in process memory before it was killed. If grafana-agent has a WAL and can replay data - 99% of the data should be delivered successfully.

messages.text: The problem is k8s backoffing the restart if it keeps OOM-ing - so eventually the restarts stretch too far for the WAL to keep being able to buffer. But yes, I'll try to get some more insight into VM itself first, to have it not go OOM 😉

text: could you please advice?

For importing feel free to use JSON or CSV (see VM docs on format). JSON is going to be smaller in size as it doesn't repeat metrics names for each row (although gzipped it might not make a big difference).
For fetching data in python just make a http request for
with any query. Or, if you need raw data --

(it supports only filters by metric/label/timerange but not aggregate functions).
I was going to do exporting to .parquet, let me know if you really want it.

text: NVM, max() did the trick.

text.text:
max(
label_del(
label_value(
  label_map(
    model_status{} == 1,
    "model_status",
    "FAILED", "-1",
    "WORKING", "1",
    "FINISHED", "0"
  ),
  "model_status"),
  "model_status")
  ) by (mandator,modelReferenceCode)

text_entities.text:
max(
label_del(
label_value(
  label_map(
    model_status{} == 1,
    "model_status",
    "FAILED", "-1",
    "WORKING", "1",
    "FINISHED", "0"
  ),
  "model_status"),
  "model_status")
  ) by (mandator,modelReferenceCode)

messages.text:
Hello experts!  
I have a question about how to estimate the disk size about VictoriaMetris database.
For example: I have 100 vms, data ingestion rate is 7.5k/s, then for 1000 vms in 1 year, what is the disk size of it?
Thanks for your kind help.

text_entities.text:
Hello experts!  
I have a question about how to estimate the disk size about VictoriaMetris database.
For example: I have 100 vms, data ingestion rate is 7.5k/s, then for 1000 vms in 1 year, what is the disk size of it?
Thanks for your kind help.

messages.text: Also, what is the compression algorithm for VictoriaMetrics?

text_entities.text: Also, what is the compression algorithm for VictoriaMetrics?

text:
Hi! VictoriaMetrics exposes metrics regarding the total number of stored datapoints and occupied disk size. Using those it is easy to estimate the usage - just spin up VictoriaMetrics, start the load and check the metrics.
I'd recommend to configure

for your installation and check the Grafana dashboard for disk usage. Using that you can extrapolate estimated usage in days/month/year
Or extrapolate by calculating avg bytes-per-datapoint size and multiply by number of datapoints you're going to store per year.

Please note, it is better to wait at least for a day or two for disk usage to settle. In the very beginning numbers might be not correct because compression didn't kick in yet.

text.text:
How do I get the real last data point, not ephemeral?
last_over_time function can be used for limiting the lookbehind window for calculated data. For example, last_over_time(metric[10s]) would return calculated samples only if the real samples are located closer than 10 seconds to the calculated timestamps according to start, end and step query args passed to range query.

for such data and described usage sceanrio VM may be not a best choice.
VM was designed for continious time series of data which are constantly collected and updated.
In order to get data in past user needs to specify the exact time range where database should look at. Otherwise, the search lookup may be too expensive.

in linux like systems, every opened connection requires a new file descriptior to open. It is a usual case to rise limit of file descriptors  for applications which accept connections from clients.

We also have an alert which is supposed to notify you that you're running out of FDs - see

text.text: vmauth is a simple auth proxy, router and load balancer for VictoriaMetrics. It reads auth credentials from Authorization http header (Basic Auth, Bearer token and InfluxDB authorization is supported), matches them against configs pointed by -auth.config command-line flag and proxies incoming HTTP requests to the configured per-user url_prefix on successful match.

text: See more at

text_entities.text: vmauth is a simple auth proxy, router and load balancer for VictoriaMetrics. It reads auth credentials from Authorization http header (Basic Auth, Bearer token and InfluxDB authorization is supported), matches them against configs pointed by -auth.config command-line flag and proxies incoming HTTP requests to the configured per-user url_prefix on successful match.

messages.text:
Hi, 
Unfortunately no, only vmutils are supported by windows OS.

But as a workaround you can enable wsl/wsl2 on  windows10/11 and run VictoriaMetrics Single there in some Linux. For production setups we recommend run VictoriaMetrics on Linux OS.

text:
http/2.0 shouldn't provide any improvements over http/1.1 for target scraping because of the following reasons:
- Every scrape target is usually located on a separate TCP address (e.g. different

). http/2.0 cannot share connections for concurrent requests to distinct TCP addresses.
- Every scrape target is scraped synchronously with the usual scrape_interval in the range

. This means that at every given time there can be only a single in-flight request to the scrape target. The main http/2.0 feature - request multiplexing over a single TCP connection - has no sense in this case, since only a single request at a time is processed per each target.
- vmagent tries keeping keep-alive connections to each target between scrapes in order to minimize the overhead on connection establishing.

On the other hand, http/2.0 has the following drawbacks when being used for target scraping:
- http/2.0 is much more complicated protocol comparing to http/1.1 . The code needed for http/2.0 support may significantly increase vmagent binary size
- http/2.0 has not-so-good security record because of its complexity. See
. Dropping support for http/2.0 makes VictoriaMetrics products more secure.

text: vmagent automatically switches to stream parsing mode when it scrapes targets, which return responses with sizes exceeding the value passed to
command-line flag. The default value for this flag is 1000000 bytes. It looks like the
returns in your case returns much bigger response. So vmagent reads data from

in stream parsing mode. In this mode vmagent reads the response in 64kb chunks, parses metrics in every chunk as soon as it has been read and immediately pushes the parsed metrics to the configured remote storage systems via
. So big response from the target can take non-trivial amounts of time (e.g. more than a minute in your case) to be read and parsed in stream parsing mode. It looks like the
or Kubernetes API server keeps other incoming requests in the queue until the response for the current request is returned to vmagent. That's why you see
errors for other
instances. Note that the
column shows the duration between the request start and receiving the first response byte. That's why you see only 11 seconds for the first

target on the screenshot above.

There are the following workarounds exist:
- To set
command-line flag to value higher that the size of the response from
and to make sure that the
mode isn't enabled via other settings described at

. In this case vmagent will read the whole response from every target into memory and then parse  it and send the parsed metrics to the configured remote storage systems. This may significantly increase the needed memory size for vmagent.
- To query

targets via caching http proxy such as nginx and to make sure that the proxy fully reads and caches the response from backend before returning it to the client (vmagent).

I'm going to explore the long-term solution for this issue - to read the full response into a temporary file and then parse it in stream parsing mode. This should shorten the time needed for reading the response from
, so it could process other incoming requests without waiting in the queue. If this solution will work as expected, then it will be included in the upcoming VictoriaMetrics release

text:
For example, i have VmServiceScrape object, and i want, that Vm scrape all services in namespace, for the exceptional ones who fall into the state. Does such an option exist?
apiVersion:

kind: VMServiceScrape
metadata:
  name: scrape
spec:
  endpoints:
  - port: http-srv
    honorLabels: true
    interval: 15s
    path: /actuator/prometheus
  namespaceSelector:
    matchNames:
    - bm
  podTargetLabels:
  - platform
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      platform: bm

text:
Hello,

 I suggest two options:
1) use relabelConfigs and filter out with action: drop by kubernetes metadata labels
2) use selector.matchExpressions syntax for exclusion:

text.text:
selector:
    matchLabels:
        platform: bm
    matchExpressions:
    - key: os
      operator: NotIn
      values: ["linux", "macos"]

text_entities.text:
Hello,

 I suggest two options:
1) use relabelConfigs and filter out with action: drop by kubernetes metadata labels
2) use selector.matchExpressions syntax for exclusion:

selector:
    matchLabels:
        platform: bm
    matchExpressions:
    - key: os
      operator: NotIn
      values: ["linux", "macos"]

messages.text: The situation like you describe could happen if data existed, then response was cached on vmselect, but then last 2d of data were deleted. Or vmstroage which held that data is down/unreachable/purged. Then what you see is the cached response.

basically, if you can confirm that  it does not corrupt the data or insert duplicate records if i run with a small overlap then i'm golden i think; I got a an agreement that I can theoretically sync on a longer interval as well if vmctl allows such usage:

Example usecase: 

Today  morning docker run victoria-vmctl [——] --influx-filter-time-start "2022-10-25T00:00:00Z" --influx-filter-time-end "2022-10-26T01:00:00Z" [—-]

tomorrow morning:

--influx-filter-time-start "2022-10-26T00:00:00Z" --influx-filter-time-end "2022-10-27T01:00:00Z" [—-]

text.text:
relabel_configs:

    annotations: {}
    # -- Service labels
    labels: {}
    # -- Service ClusterIP
    clusterIP: ""
    externalIPs: []
    # -- Service load balancer IP
    loadBalancerIP: ""
    # -- Load balancer source range
    loadBalancerSourceRanges: []
    # -- Service port
    servicePort: 4242
    # -- Service type
    type: ClusterIP
    # -- Enable UDP port. used if you have "spec.opentsdbListenAddr" specified
    udp: false

text: That will change service endpoint to point at opentsdb port and ingress should route it correctly.

text_entities.text: You will just need to change servicePort to 4242:

service:
    # -- Service annotations
    annotations: {}
    # -- Service labels
    labels: {}
    # -- Service ClusterIP
    clusterIP: ""
    externalIPs: []
    # -- Service load balancer IP
    loadBalancerIP: ""
    # -- Load balancer source range
    loadBalancerSourceRanges: []
    # -- Service port
    servicePort: 4242
    # -- Service type
    type: ClusterIP
    # -- Enable UDP port. used if you have "spec.opentsdbListenAddr" specified
    udp: false
That will change service endpoint to point at opentsdb port and ingress should route it correctly.

messages.text: Thanks

So try to explain by steps:
1. First of all be sure that retentioPeriod set correctly in your storage node
2. Run import command
curl http://localhost:8480/insert/0/prometheus/api/v1/import  -d '{"metric":{"__name__":"foo","job":"node_exporter"},"values":[0,1,2],"timestamps":[1549891472010,1549891487724,1549891503438]}' -X POST

3. Run export after import
curl -G http://localhost:8481/select/0/prometheus/api/v1/export -d 'match={__name__="foo"}' 
4. You should see next response:

The following indirect indicators can be used for determining disk space usage per each metric name:

- If there are many unique time series with the same metric name, then it is likely these time series will occupy significant amounts of disk space because of the following reasons:
  1. All the
pairs per every new time series are registered in the inverted index (aka
), which is stored on disk. So the disk space usage for

grows linearly with the total number of time series stored in the database.
  2. If every unique time series contains small number of samples (e.g. less than 1000), then it cannot be compressed efficiently.
 The main source of big number of unique time series is a churn rate. See
. The
tab at
can be used for determining metric names, which match the biggest number of unique time series - see

- Metric values with big number of semi-random digits usually cannot be compressed well. The usual source of such values is some calculations on top of raw measurements. For example, the average cpu usage on top of
counter, e.g. if you store the results of
into VictoriaMetrics via recording rules (see
). It is recommended to strip "white noise" digits from the calculated results before storing them into VictoriaMetrics. This can be done with
function - see

- Irregular interval between samples stored per each time series may result in increased disk usage, since timestamps for such samples cannot be compressed well.

- Disk space usage usually grows linearly with the number of samples stored on disk. So smaller intervals between samples (aka small
) increase disk space usage.

Thank you very much I will do that. I was seeing changes in disk usage despite no change in sample rates(for some reason other than merges) and wanted to understand the reason. 
To my current knowledge, following issues might lead to variation in disk usage without any change in the system; am I right?
- Frequent  network issues causing disruption in scrapes or remotewrites (causes irregular intervals)
- Excess significant figures in data and noise issue of recording rules (fixed by round())
- Frequent rolling updates regarding k8s deployments (causes more churn and cardinality and compression problem)
I have checked the data stored on disk and timestamp.bin and values.bin are comparable in size and index.bin is much less. (19.1GiB v.s 17.6 GiB v.s. 700MiB) Is this normal?

text:
That's correct list of issues. The storage size distribution between timestamps.bin, values.bin and index.bin look good.

The disk usage can jump up/down because of background merges of smaller data parts into bigger data parts. The merge process requires additional disk space while creating bigger data part. When it is ready, it is atomically swapped with the smaller source data parts, so the disk usage goes down. See
for more details

[Irrelevant to previous message] 

Is there a way to reduce indexdb rotation period to a value other than half of retention period? I saw the code but I couldn’t find any options.
We may have a network or cluster incident that causes very high churn rates in transient. In such casess indexdb size is dramatically higher (2x) than the data itself and it keeps going like forever(untill indexdb rotation)! I can’t fix the problem even if I delete the problematic timeseries from the vm.

It also helps if there is a manual way for indexdb rebuild.
(Additionally, this may be helpfull when you change the retention on a storage)

messages.text:
Hello, we are currently using VM as a replacement for Prometheus pull-based data collection.
We wanted to support push-based data via one of the protocols the VM supports.
Do you have any recommendations between the supported protocols?
Since we need to use it with C++ clients, I was mainly looking at DataDog and InfluxDB.

text_entities.text:
Hello, we are currently using VM as a replacement for Prometheus pull-based data collection.
We wanted to support push-based data via one of the protocols the VM supports.
Do you have any recommendations between the supported protocols?
Since we need to use it with C++ clients, I was mainly looking at DataDog and InfluxDB.

text: Hi

! All protocols go through the same code path internally. So besides parsing complexity there is no difference among protocols.
I personally prefer influxdb protocol - it is simple, compact and human readable.

text_entities.text:

messages.text: Hi! It is for propagating cache invalidation command when one vmselect receives it. For example, you had a metric queried and cached on multiple vmselects. Then you decide to delete that metric and do a call to delete API. Only one vmselect will serve your delete API request, and if it has -selectNode flag configured - it would send cache invalidation request for this metric name to all the listed vmselects.

text_entities.text: Hi! It is for propagating cache invalidation command when one vmselect receives it. For example, you had a metric queried and cached on multiple vmselects. Then you decide to delete that metric and do a call to delete API. Only one vmselect will serve your delete API request, and if it has -selectNode flag configured - it would send cache invalidation request for this metric name to all the listed vmselects.

messages.text:
Hello!
I want to create a new 'hostname' metric whose value is taken from the 'nodename' label from the 'node_uname_info' metric that is provided by the node_exporter.
I think this is possible with "metric_relabel_configs".
Is it possible? If yes, how does it work?

text_entities.text:
Hello!
I want to create a new 'hostname' metric whose value is taken from the 'nodename' label from the 'node_uname_info' metric that is provided by the node_exporter.
I think this is possible with "metric_relabel_configs".
Is it possible? If yes, how does it work?

messages.photo: (File not included. Change data exporting settings to download.)
text:
Hello!
Yes, it is possible to do this by using the following relabeling configuration:

text.text:
metric_relabel_configs:
  - action: replace
    source_labels: [nodename]
    target_label: "__name__"
    if: node_uname_info

text: This relabeling uses pseudo-label
in order to create new metric based on
label from

metric.
It will replace original metric name with value provided in

label of this metric.
See the attached screenshot from vmagent debugging UI

text_entities.text:
Hello!

    source_labels: [nodename]
    target_label: "__name__"
    if: node_uname_info
in order to create new metric based on

metric.
It will replace original metric name with value provided in

label of this metric.
See the attached screenshot from vmagent debugging UI

text: So you can use the follwoing flag:

text.text:
-remoteWrite.rateLimit array
     Optional rate limit in bytes per second for data sent to the corresponding -remoteWrite.url. By default the rate limit is disabled. It can be useful for limiting load on remote storage when big amounts of buffered data is sent after temporary unavailability of the remote storage
     Supports array of values separated by comma or specified via multiple flags.
